TopicTitle: The Delta IV Orion Launch... RECORDING HERE! (Soon)

Articles.Content:
Well BALLS. JUST got home to find the my thread explode from 5 pages to 25. O.O

But yeah- disappointment? How about I got a flat *** from sitting on flat metal for 5+ hours and whats my reward?

I got to talk to the astronaut with the most flights on the shuttle . But yeah- I can tell you what happened and when. Granted I'm a little dizzy from being away almost 24 hours straight but Idc at this point.

Also note-

Today was my ONLY possible attempt at watching it... I simply cant be there for Fridays... BUT I could be there for SATURDAY'S launch instead should tomorrow blow over as today did.
Which may happen Zoo. Weather is suppose to be worse tomorrow morning.

Which may happen Zoo. Weather is suppose to be worse tomorrow morning.

We'll see. :/ .
I was rather dissapointed too, I watched it all morning on NASA TV, can't tell you how angry I was when they said "Hold....Wind violation" I literally slammed my desk the second time in a hype rage

Hey, I had to watch the stream all day long on my iPhone, ended up wasting my 500MB of data that I had for December.

I wasted them all in one day lol feel terrible too.

I woke up and was like "Crap! I missed the launch!" and turned it on only to see I hadn't. But I realized it probably wasn't going to happen till after I got to work, then they say "5 minutes to launch.". I'm all "Ooh! I can delay heading out for 5-10 minutes." Yeah...that was at like 8:10 or so. Didn't leave home till like 8:50 when I said "$%@# it, I have to get to work. I'll just have it on my phone the whole way there." As I pull into my parking space "Mission Scrub is in effect. Secure all stations.". I almost slammed my forehead into my steering wheel.

I was rather dissapointed too, I watched it all morning on NASA TV, can't tell you how angry I was when they said "Hold....Wind violation" I literally slammed my desk the second time in a hype rage

The entire crowd at the viewing center was wanting to murder the boat guy XD. I am NOT joking either .

You knew the Air Force wasn't screwing around after that when they had a Apache flying overhead every 5 minutes.

I was only able to watch for the first hour of the window. Was sad when it got delayed more, but as it turns out it got delayed so much the thing never even launch at all....

But there is always tomorrow, and the next day... and the next day... and the next day... and the next day...

The more I think about it, the more I have the feeling, that the LES was real. It hast to jettison the upper fairing, once it's in space. Also I can't imagine that the LES is that expensive (compared to the rest of the vessel).

Let's hope the boat guy didn't jinx it.

I mean, we all still remember what happened last time we had a launch attempt the day after a boat in the range caused issues...

Fun fact, by the way: the airforce confirmed that it was a barge being towed. Has the entire SpaceX fancrowd up in a buzz, even though the chances of it being Elon's mobile landing pad are slim to none.

Let's hope the boat guy didn't jinx it.

I mean, we all still remember what happened last time we had a launch attempt the day after a boat in the range caused issues... :sealed:QUOTE]

What happened last time o.o ??

This:

Also, another interesting tidbit on the boat - apparently it wasn't in the hazard area after all. It just skirted the edge really closely, which caused the airforce to throw up alarms first and only afterwards start properly calculating the actual position. When they finished calculating it turned out that there was no violation.

.

I mean, we all still remember what happened last time we had a launch attempt the day after a boat in the range caused issues...

I noticed this earlier today as well. Dun dun dunnnn.

This:

Also, another interesting tidbit on the boat - apparently it wasn't in the hazard area after all. It just skirted the edge really closely, which caused the airforce to throw up alarms first and only afterwards start properly calculating the actual position. When they finished calculating it turned out that there was no violation.

.

I know. I show the post-mission briefing.

This:

Also, another interesting tidbit on the boat - apparently it wasn't in the hazard area after all. It just skirted the edge really closely, which caused the airforce to throw up alarms first and only afterwards start properly calculating the actual position. When they finished calculating it turned out that there was no violation.

.

Ah. I see.

Don't explode, don't explode, don't explode...

If it does, I am hunting the Boat Moron down:mad:

The more I think about it, the more I have the feeling, that the LES was real. It hast to jettison the upper fairing, once it's in space. Also I can't imagine that the LES is that expensive (compared to the rest of the vessel).

For freak's sake people. It's a dummy LAS with jettison motors and ballast, no abort motors, attitude motors or avionics.
Everyone ready for take 2?
Only a 40% chance of weather good enough to launch during the window, do not be surprised if it gets scrubbed again.

Well, the rain has cleared off, let's just hope that the clouds and wind decide to cooperate too.

Source: I was getting wet, and now I'm not

Correction- I cannot make Saturday's launch (If this one weren't to go up).

So- I'm sorry but I cannot help any further.

Have they already scrubbed it for today? Nasa TV is just playing the usual stuff.. coverage was supposed to start at 6.

... nevermind.
they're just doing their propaganda before the interesting stuff starts happening with the rocket.
Not sure you could call it propaganda but whatever floats your boat! maybe we are watching two different things.
